facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 359 of 1964 was an appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated September 29, 1961 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 123 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 359 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated September 29, 1961 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 123 of 1958.

facts.text: The High Court of Madhya Pradesh confirmed the decree of the Additional District Judge, Hoshangabad, decreeing the plaintiff's suit.

anchor.surface_text: confirming the decree of the Additional District Judge, Hoshangabad, decreeing the plaintiffs suit. The State of Madhya Pradesh has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: An auction was held on July 20, 1954 by the Divisional Forest Officer, Hoshangabad Division, for sale of felled trees in Coupe No. 66 Dhekna, Range Seoni.

anchor.surface_text: At an auction held on July 20, 1954 by the Divisional Forest Officer, Hoshangabad Division, for sale of felled trees in Coupe No. 66 Dhekna, Range Seoni, one Jagatram was declared the highest bidder

facts.text: Jagatram was declared the highest bidder and the trees were sold to him for Rs. 12,100.

anchor.surface_text: , one Jagatram was declared the highest bidder and the trees were sold to him for Rs. 12,100. The amount of the bid was payable in four instalments of Rs. 3,025 each

facts.text: The bid amount was payable in four instalments of Rs. 3,025 each: first immediately, second on December 1, 1954, third on February 1, 1955, fourth on May 1, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The amount of the bid was payable in four instalments of Rs. 3,025 each the first instalment to be paid immediately on acceptance of the bid, the second on December 1, 1954, the third on February 1, 1955 and the fourth on May 1, 1955.

facts.text: Jagatram executed a contract in favour of the Governor of Madhya Pradesh incorporating the terms and conditions of the sale.

anchor.surface_text: Jagatram executed a contract in favour of the Governor of Madhya Pradesh in which were incorporated the terms and conditions of the sale.

facts.text: Jagatram paid the first instalment on July 28, 1954, and subscribed his signature to the terms of the contract.

anchor.surface_text: Jagatram paid the first instalment due under the contract on July 28, 1954, and subscribed his signature to the terms of the contract.

facts.text: Nathuram and Kaluram stood sureties for Jagatram and executed a surety bond.

anchor.surface_text: Nathuram and Kaluram stood sureties for him and executed the following bond Whereas the Governor in order to secure the due performance of conditions of the above contract demanded security from the forest contractor,

facts.text: Jagatram removed almost the entire quantity of trees sold to him.

anchor.surface_text: Jagatram removed almost the entire quantity of trees sold to him, but since he did not pay the remaining three instalments of the price,

facts.text: Jagatram did not pay the remaining three instalments.

anchor.surface_text: but since he did not pay the remaining three instalments of the price, the State of Madhya Pradesh took proceedings to recover from Kaluram the amount due by Jagatram

facts.text: State of Madhya Pradesh took proceedings to recover from Kaluram the amount due by Jagatram as arrears of land revenue.

anchor.surface_text: the State of Madhya Pradesh took proceedings to recover from Kaluram the amount due by Jagatram as arrears of land revenue.

facts.text: Kaluram commenced an action against the State of Madhya Pradesh for declaration that he was not liable to pay the arrears and for injunction restraining recovery.

anchor.surface_text: Kaluram then commenced an action against the State of Madhya Pradesh for a declaration that he was not liable to pay the arrears of forest dues recoverable from Jagatram and for an injunction restraining the State from realising

facts.text: Kaluram's principal ground was that forest authorities gave time to Jagatram and omitted to seize and sell trees after second instalment due, impairing remedy against Jagatram.

anchor.surface_text: The principal ground in support of the claim was that the forest authorities gave time to Jagatram and omitted to take steps which their duty to the surety required them to take i.e., prompt seizure and sale of the trees after the second instalment had fallen due,

facts.text: Trial Court held forest officers negligent in allowing contractor to remove trees, impairing surety's security, discharging surety.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court held that the forest officers were negligent in allowing the contractor Jagatram to remove the trees sold, and on that account the security of the surety was impaired, and the surety stood discharged

facts.text: High Court of Madhya Pradesh confirmed the decree of the Trial Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Madhya Pradesh confirmed the decree of the Trial Court.

facts.text: Forest authorities allowed Jagatram to remove the goods sold before instalments due on December 1, 1954 and thereafter were paid.

anchor.surface_text: The forest authorities however allowed Jagatram to remove the goods sold before the instalments due on December 1, 1954 and thereafter were paid.

facts.text: State has not produced the accounts furnished under r. 16 by the contractor relating to quantity removed by Jagatram.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the State has not produced the accounts furnished under r. 16 by the contractor relating to the quantity of goods removed by Jagatram.

facts.text: Court holds that entire quantity contracted to be sold to Jagatram had been removed.

anchor.surface_text: We must in the circumstances hold that the entire quantity contracted to be sold to Jagatram had been removed, and the surety is, because the State has parted with the security

facts.text: Nathuram son of Kashiram resident of Chaterkheda and Kaluram son of Jhandusingh resident of PipaliyaKalan, agriculturists, were sureties.

anchor.surface_text: I Nathuram son of- Kashiram resident of Chaterkheda Kaluram son of Jhandusingh resident of PipaliyaKalan, by occupation Agriculturists, surety on behalf of the forest contractor,

facts.text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J.

anchor.surface_text: Sen J.P. Dube and I.N. Shroff, for the appellant C. Misra and S. S. Shukla, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J,

facts.text: Sen J.P. Dube and I.N. Shroff appeared for the appellant, C. Misra and S. S. Shukla for the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Sen J.P. Dube and I.N. Shroff, for the appellant C. Misra and S. S. Shukla, for the respondent.

facts.text: State of Madhya Pradesh is the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Madhya Pradesh has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Kaluram is the plaintiff in the suit.

anchor.surface_text: decreeing the plaintiffs suit.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated September 29, 1961 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 123 of 1958.

concepts.interpretation: Imposes a first charge on forest produce for the price thereof, allowing seizure and sale if unpaid; constitutes a security for the creditor.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 140 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872, where a guaranteed debt has become due, or default of the principal debtor to perform a guaranteed duty has taken place, the surety, upon payment or performance of all that he is liable for, is invested with all the rights which the creditor had against the principal debtor

concepts.interpretation: Surety subrogated to creditor's rights upon payment.
concepts.unlisted_description: Subrogation of surety to creditor's rights

anchor.surface_text: and by s. 141 it is provided A surety is entitled to the benefit of every security which the creditor has against the principal debtor at the time when the companytract of suretyship is entered into, whether the surety knows of the existence of such security or number and, if the creditor loses, or, without companysent of the surety, parts with such security, the surety is discharged to the extent of the value of the security.

concepts.interpretation: Surety discharged to the extent of value of security lost or parted with by creditor without surety's consent; 'security' includes all rights against the property, such as charge and right to possession/control over goods.
concepts.unlisted_description: Discharge of surety on creditor parting with security

concepts.interpretation: Authority to stop removal if value removed exceeds payments made; part of security.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 29 1  provides that a forest companytract may be, terminated by the Office empowered to execute it on behalf of the Government, if the Forest companytractor makes default in the payment of the companysideration for his companytract or of any instalment thereof, or companymits a breach of any of the other companyditions of his companytract. By sub-r.  2  of r. 29 it is provided that such termination shall be numberified to the forest companytractor by a written numberice and thereupon all the companytractors rights under the companytract including all accessory licences shall cease and all the forest produce remaining within the companytract area or at the depots specified under r. 13 shall become the absolute property of Government.

concepts.interpretation: Termination for default vests remaining produce in government; implies prior ownership with contractor.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: security which the creditor has against the principal debtor at the time when the companytract of s

anchor.surface_text: Rule 33 1  provides that all forest produce removed from a companytract area in accordance with the rules and duly checked and passed at the depots established under r. 13 shall be at the absolute disposal of the forest companytractor. By cl.  2  of r. 33 it is provided that the forest companytractor may assign any forest produce number so removed, but such assignment shall number be valid unless it is made with the previous sanction in writing of the forest officer who executed the companytract.

concepts.interpretation: Checked and passed produce at disposal of contractor, who may assign with permission; supports ownership.

issues.text: Whether the property in the felled trees passed to Jagatram upon production of the type boundary certificate by virtue of s. 20 of the Sale of Goods Act?

anchor.surface_text: The contract between Jagatram and the State was in respect of felled trees and the area and denomination of the type were set out. The trees agreed to be sold being in a deliverable state, by virtue of s. 20 of the Sale of Goods Act, the property in the goods sold passed on the production of the type boundary certificate.

issues.text: Whether the statutory charge under s. 83 of the Indian Forest Act attached to the goods sold even after property passed to the forest contractor?

anchor.surface_text: The argument of the State that the property in the goods had number passed to the forest companytractor till they were removed, and on that account the statutory charge under s. 83 of the Forest Act did number attach to the goods sold, has therefore numberforce.

issues.text: Whether the forest authorities parted with or lost the security by allowing Jagatram to remove the goods without payment of the instalments due?

anchor.surface_text: As soon as the companytract was entered into and the companype boundary certificate was produced and we assume in this case that it was so produced, the property in the goods passed to Jagatram. But for the companytract price there was a first charge on such produce in favour of the State of Madhya Pradesh under s. 83 1 .

issues.text: Whether under s. 141 of the Indian Contract Act the surety is discharged to the extent of the value of the security lost or parted with by the creditor without consent of the surety?

anchor.surface_text: By s. 140 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872, where a guaranteed debt has become due, or default of the principal debtor to perform a guaranteed duty has taken place, the surety, upon payment or performance of all that he is liable for, is invested with all the rights which the creditor had against the principal debtor

issues.text: Whether mere inaction on the part of the forest authorities amounts to parting with the security so as to discharge the surety?

anchor.surface_text: It was urged however on behalf of the State that mere inaction on the part of the forest authorities does number amount to parting with the security. But the terms of the statute do number apply only to cases in which by positive action on the part of the creditor the security is parted with.

issues.text: Whether the surety Kaluram stood fully discharged from liability given the State's failure to produce accounts under r. 16 showing quantity removed?

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the State has number produced the accounts furnished under r. 16 by the companytractor relating to the quantity of goods removed by Jagatram. We must in the circumstances hold that the entire quantity companytracted to be sold to Jagatram had been removed,

anchor.surface_text: The principal ground in support of the claim was that the forest authorities gave time to Jagatram and omitted to take steps which their duty to the surety required them to take i.e., prompt seizure and sale of the trees after the second instalment had fallen due,

arguments.court_reasoning: Forest authorities parted with security by allowing removal without payment, applying s.141 Contract Act

arguments.claim: Property in felled trees passed to Jagatram on production of type boundary certificate by virtue of s.20 Sale of Goods Act

anchor.surface_text: The contract between Jagatram and the State was in respect of felled trees and the area and denomination of the type were set out. The trees agreed to be sold being in a deliverable state, by virtue of s. 20 of the Sale of Goods Act, the property in the goods sold passed on the production of the type boundary certificate.

arguments.claim: Statutory first charge under s.83 Indian Forest Act on forest produce for contract price, survives property passing to contractor; right to seize/sell remains as security

anchor.surface_text: As soon as the contract was entered into and the type boundary certificate was produced and we assume in this case that it was so produced, the property in the goods passed to Jagatram. But for the contract price there was a first charge on such produce in favour of the State of Madhya Pradesh under s. 83 (1).

arguments.claim: Forest authorities parted with security by allowing removal of goods before instalments paid, discharging surety under s.141 Contract Act to extent of security value

anchor.surface_text: The Divisional Forest Officer had authority to stop removal of those goods until the amount of instalments payable by the contractor was paid and even to sell the goods for recovery of the amount which had fallen due. The forest authorities however allowed Jagatram to remove the goods sold before the instalments due on December 1, 1954 and thereafter were paid.

arguments.claim: Under s.141 Indian Contract Act, surety entitled to every security creditor had at suretyship contract; creditor parting with/losing security without surety consent discharges surety to extent of security value; security includes charge and rights to possession/control/stop removal

anchor.surface_text: By s. 140 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872, where a guaranteed debt has become due, or default of the principal debtor to perform a guaranteed duty has taken place, the surety, upon payment or performance of all that he is liable for, is invested with all the rights which the creditor had against the principal debtor

arguments.claim: State failed to produce accounts under r.16; presume entire quantity contracted sold to Jagatram was removed, so full security parted with, fully discharging surety

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the State has not produced the accounts furnished under r. 16 by the contractor relating to the quantity of goods removed by Jagatram. We must in the circumstances hold that the entire quantity contracted to be sold to Jagatram had been removed,

arguments.claim: Mere inaction by forest authorities does not amount to parting with security
arguments.court_reasoning: s.141 applies even to security lost by creditor, not just positive parting; here not mere inaction but permission to remove

arguments.claim: s.141 Contract Act incorporates English law; surety discharged if creditor loses/permits debtor possession of security or fails to make effectual
Forest Officers parted with goods/control before payment; charge impaired, power to sell ineffective, right to prevent removal lost; constitutes parting with security

holdings.text: The property in the felled trees sold passed to Jagatram upon production of the type boundary certificate by virtue of s. 20 of the Sale of Goods Act.

anchor.surface_text: The contract between Jagatram and the State was in respect of felled trees and the area and denomination of the type were set out. The trees agreed to be sold being in a deliverable state, by virtue of s. 20 of the Sale of Goods Act, the property in the goods sold passed on the production of the type boundary certificate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Felled trees in deliverable state; specific goods; property passes when contract made on production of certificate; rules do not prevent ownership transfer.

holdings.text: The statutory charge under s. 83 of the Indian Forest Act attached to the goods sold even after property passed to the forest contractor.

anchor.surface_text: The argument of the State that the property in the goods had not passed to the forest contractor till they were removed, and on that account the statutory charge under s. 83 of the Forest Act did not attach to the goods sold, has therefore no force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charge arises for contract price regardless of property passing; right to seize/sell persists as security.

holdings.text: The forest authorities parted with the security by allowing Jagatram to remove the goods before payment of instalments due.

anchor.surface_text: As soon as the contract was entered into and the type boundary certificate was produced and we assume in this case that it was so produced, the property in the goods passed to Jagatram. But for the contract price there was a first charge on such produce in favour of the State of Madhya Pradesh under s. 83 (1).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Authority under r.8 to stop removal and s.83 to seize/sell; permission to remove without payment lost control/charge.

holdings.text: Under s. 141 of the Indian Contract Act, the surety is discharged to the extent of the value of the security lost or parted with by the creditor without the surety's consent.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 140 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872, where a guaranteed debt has become due, or default of the principal debtor to perform a guaranteed duty has taken place, the surety, upon payment or performance of all that he is liable for, is invested with all the rights which the creditor had against the principal debtor

holdings.reasoning_summary: Security includes charge and rights to possession/control; surety entitled to all such benefits at time of suretyship contract.

holdings.text: Mere inaction or loss of security by the creditor discharges the surety under s. 141; not limited to positive parting with security.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statute covers loss of security; here permission to remove and failure to enforce not mere inaction.

holdings.text: The surety Kaluram stood fully discharged from liability as the entire quantity of trees was removed and State parted with full security, evidenced by failure to produce r.16 accounts.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the State has not produced the accounts furnished under r. 16 by the contractor relating to the quantity of goods removed by Jagatram. We must in the circumstances hold that the entire quantity contracted to be sold to Jagatram had been removed,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presumption from non-production of accounts; full security lost discharges surety completely.

holdings.text: The surety Kaluram stood discharged from liability because the forest authorities parted with the security for recovery of the amount due from the contractor.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirmation of lower courts; application of s.141 to facts of removal without payment impairing charge and rights.

precedents.citation: Wulff and Billing v. Jay, 1 Hannen, J.

anchor.surface_text: In Wulff and Billing v. Jay, 1  Hannen, J., stated the law thus I take it to be established that the defendant became surety upon the faith of there being some real and substantial security pledged, as well as his own credit, to the plaintiff and he was entitled, therefore, to the benefit of that real and substantial security in the event of his being called on to fulfill his duty as a surety, and to pay the debt for which he had so become- surety.

precedents.cited_proposition: surety is discharged from liability if the creditors have put it out of their power to hand over to the surety the means of recouping himself by the security given by the principal
precedents.cited_holding: I take it to be established that the defendant became surety upon the faith of there being some real and substantial security pledged, as well as his own credit, to the plaintiff and he was entitled, therefore, to the benefit of that real and substantial security in the event of his being called on to fulfill his duty as a surety, and to pay the debt for which he had so become surety. He will, however, be discharged from his liability as surety if the creditors have put it out of their power to hand over to the surety the means of recouping himself by the security given by the principal.

anchor.surface_text: That doctrine is very clearly expressed in the notes in Rees v. Barrington-2 White Tudors C., 4th Edn. at p. 1002-As a surety, on payment of the debt, is entitled to all the securities of the creditor, whether he is aware of their existence or number, even though they were given after the companytract of suretyship, if the creditor who has had, or ought to have had, them in his full po ssession or power, loses them or permits them to get into the possession of the debtor, or does number make them effectual by giving proper numberice, the surety to the extent of such security will be discharged.

precedents.cited_proposition: surety is discharged to the extent of security lost if creditor loses securities or permits them to get into possession of debtor or does not make them effectual
precedents.cited_holding: As a surety, on payment of the debt, is entitled to all the securities of the creditor, whether he is aware of their existence or number, even though they were given after the companytract of suretyship, if the creditor who has had, or ought to have had, them in his full po ssession or power, loses them or permits them to get into the possession of the debtor, or does number make them effectual by giving proper numberice, the surety to the extent of such security will be discharged. A surety, moreover, will be released if the creditor, by reason of what he has done, cannot, on payment by the surety, give him the securities in exactly the same companydition as they formerly stood in his hands.

Rule 29 implies prior ownership of produce with the contractor, supporting the holding that property in felled trees passed to Jagatram.
Rule 29 on termination vesting remaining produce in government, implying prior contractor ownership, addresses the issue of when property in felled trees passes to the contractor.
Concept explicitly notes Rule 33 'supports ownership', aligning with holding h1 that property in felled trees passed to contractor Jagatram.
Concept describes produce at 'disposal of contractor' under Rule 33, supporting holding that authorities parted with security by allowing removal.

Section 83 constitutes the security that could be parted with by forest authorities

anchor.surface_text: The contract between Jagatram and the State was in respect of felled trees and the area and denomination of the type were set out. The trees agreed to be sold being in a deliverable state, by virtue of s. 20 of the Sale of Goods Act, the property in the goods sold passed on the production of the type boundary certificate.

We therefore agree with the High Court that the surety Kalu- ram stood discharged from liability to pay the amount undertaken by him under the terms of the surety bond because the forest authorities of the State had parted

anchor.surface_text: The argument of the State that the property in the goods had not passed to the forest contractor till they were removed, and on that account the statutory charge under s. 83 of the Forest Act did not attach to the goods sold, has therefore no force.

We therefore agree with the High Court that the surety Kalu- ram stood discharged from liability to pay the amount undertaken by him under the terms of the surety bond because the forest authorities of the State had parted
